title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.15.45-46 | 01-01-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: The younger brothers of Maharaja Yudhishthira observed that the age of Kali had already arrived throughout the world, and that the citizens of the kingdom were already affected by irreligious practice.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 45, explaining that Yudhishthira's younger brothers decided to follow his example due to the influence of the age of Kali and the rise of irreligious practices.

segments.key_quote: There is no training for understanding that we are spirit souls, we belong to the spiritual world, we have to prepare for stopping the cycle of birth and death, we should prepare for going to the spiritual world.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Srila Prabhupada's purport, contrasting the traditional Vedic education system (gurukul) that emphasized both material and spiritual knowledge with modern education, which primarily focuses on material well-being.

segments.key_quote: Srila Prabhupada many times says that in India, in the Vedic culture, even the most illiterate person in a remote part of any village will know that I am not this body, I am spirit soul.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses how even the lower classes in Vedic society were aware of the ultimate goal of life, contrasting this with the ignorance of modern educated individuals regarding the nature of the self.

segments.key_quote: So what is the spiritual duty of everyone? Simply to render devotional service to Lord Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that the spiritual duty is to render devotional service to Krishna, simplified in this age by chanting Hare Krishna, and discusses the Vedic injunction to retire from family life for self-realization.

segments.key_quote: Here is a decision by authorities like the Pandavas. All of them engage themselves in favorably culturing the devotional service of the Lord the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Pandavas engaged in devotional service even after retirement and that even Moksha is not the ultimate goal of life.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is the ultimate goal of life.
segments.summary: The speaker quotes the Bhagavad Gita to emphasize that Krishna is the ultimate goal of life, and the Pandavas understood this without hesitation.

segments.key_quote: They all had performed all the principles of religion and as a result rightly decided that the lotus feet of the Lord Sri Krishna are the supreme goal of all.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 46, explaining that the Pandavas meditated on the lotus feet of Krishna as the supreme goal, and only those who have performed pious deeds can concentrate on the lotus feet of Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Arjuna, even though he knew that this was a fair battle for a just cause, still, when it came to actually killing his own kinsmen, he hesitated.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Arjuna's hesitation to kill his kinsmen as a sign of being a pure devotee, naturally kind and soft-hearted, and averse to sinful activities.

segments.key_quote: It is quite reasonable therefore that they concentrated their minds upon the lotus feet of the Supreme Lord Sri Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by stating that the Pandavas concentrated on the lotus feet of Krishna, and that dharma, artha, kama, and moksha are intermediate steps to complete surrender to Krishna, and that the Pandavas fixed their attention on the lotus feet of Krishna in the spiritual world.
